content.webTitle: New Met police chief Bernard Hogan-Howe promises 'war on crime'

fields.headline: New Met police chief Bernard Hogan-Howe promises 'war on crime'
fields.bodyText: The new head of the Metropolitan police told rank and file officers on Tuesday night that when fighting crime "no tactic – if it works – will be considered out of bounds. If it's legal, ethical, and done in good faith, I'm prepared to consider it." Bernard Hogan-Howe made the comments in an internal video mission statement to his force, in which he promised to cut crime and slash costs with "humility, transparency and integrity". Hogan-Howe, who beat Stephen House, Sir Hugh Orde and former acting commissioner Tim Godwin to the job on Monday, said that during the selection process – which included rounds of interviews with the Home Office and Metropolitan Police Authority – he made a promise that he wanted to make the Met "the best police service in the UK, and … in the world." He set out three aims: "To cut crime, cut costs, and continue to develop the culture of the organisation – our diversity and the way we relate to each other – and to do all that based on simple but important values of humility, transparency and integrity." The former chief of Merseyside police, talked of wanting to do "total policing … Some of you might recognise that phrase from my time in Merseyside" he said, "For those of you that don't, what I'm talking about is a war on crime." But as well as wanting to make the Met a force "that criminals will fear", he said he also wanted to focus on crime prevention and on caring for the victims of crime. Hogan-Howe is taking over the £260,000-a-year post after his predecessor, Sir Paul Stephenson, resigned over the phone-hacking scandal.
